thread.title: Amazon Sales Top Estimates on Prime Day Event, Cloud-Computing
thread.title_full: Amazon Sales Top Estimates on Prime Day Event, Cloud-Computing - Bloomberg Business

author: Spencer Soper
title: Amazon Sales Top Estimates on Prime Day Event, Cloud-Computing
text:
Amazon.com Inc.’s third-quarter sales topped analysts’ estimates thanks to its growing cloud-computing division, a boost from its July Prime Day promotion and a watchful eye on spending.
Revenue was $25.4 billion, Amazon said Thursday in a statement, compared with analysts’ average projection of $24.9 billion, according to data compiled by Bloomberg. Sales were $20.6 billion a year earlier, when Amazon’s stock tumbled due to little demand for the Fire smartphone.
Investors have regained confidence in Amazon as the world’s biggest Internet commerce company expanded its core business and the fast-growing cloud-computing division without spending a lot to develop new gadgets. The Seattle-based company’s shares have gained 82 percent this year.
“Jeff Bezos whiffed with the Fire phone last year and he realized he has to keep Wall Street happy because he pays people with stock,” Michael Pachter, an analyst at Wedbush Securities Inc, said regarding Amazon’s chief executive officer. “The upside here is coming from less spending on stupid products like the Fire phone.”
Amazon projected fourth-quarter revenue of $33.5 billion to $36.8 billion, compared with analysts’ average estimates of $35.1 billion. U.S. e-commerce sales are expected to hit $79.4 billion in November and December, up 14 percent from a year earlier, according to EMarketer, showing that spending continues to shift online from brick-and-mortar retailers.
The cloud division generated third-quarter revenue of $2.09 billion, an increase of 78 percent from a year earlier. Analysts’ estimated sales of $2 billion, according to an average of five estimates compiled by Bloomberg.
Amazon reported a profit of $79 million, or 17 cents a share, from a loss of $437 million, or 95 cents. Analysts’ estimated a loss of $57.6 million, or 13 cents. Operating expenses increased 18 percent to $24.9 billion, the company said.
